items.title: Anchors of Hope: Women driving recovery and resilience - Syria
items.summary: In the village of Deir Khabiyeh, located in Syria’s Rural Damascus governorate, Fatima Mohammed, 34 years with quite a heavy burden. The weight of trauma, uncertainty, and poverty is real, but Fatima has refused to give up.

items.title: Gender Equality, food and nutrition security: What can science and innovation contribute?
items.summary: Jemimah Njuki - I believe there are four key areas where science and innovation can contribute to the triple win of gender equality, food and nutrition security and the empowerment of women.

items.title: Empowering young women in agrifood systems: Insights from the WFF Youth Initiative at CSW69
items.summary: Held on 19 March at the Liaison Office of the Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations (FAO) in New York and streamed online, the event gathered over 300 youth leaders, policymakers and experts to discuss how education and training can empower young women in agrifood systems.

Women play critical roles in agrifood systems as farmers, entrepreneurs, and community leaders. However, their...

items.title: Towards a Sustainable Future: Empowering rural women in Saudi Arabia through sustainable rural agriculture
items.summary: Women have a central role and are at the heart of agrifood systems, driving transformation and advancing economic, environmental, and social progress required for sustainable development. Women’s empowerment is not only beneficial to individuals and but also crucial for the well-being of fa...

items.title: The climate crisis is unjust for rural women: FAO gender expert
items.category: Gender and emergencies and resilience building
items.summary: Rural communities worldwide are grappling with escalating challenges brought on by the climate crisis. As disasters become more frequent and severe, and environmental conditions grow harsher, the burden on these communities intensifies. However, it is women who are bearing the heaviest brunt of these impacts, including significant financial losses.

items.title: Connecting the dots in forest monitoring in Paraguay
items.summary: The fight against deforestation in Paraguay is getting a boost from an unlikely source: cutting-edge technology and data from space, coupled with the expertise of local forest conservationists. items.title: 7 success factors to empowering rural women through ICTs
items.summary: The digital revolution has changed the way we work, access information and connect with each other. It offers opportunities to those who can use the new technologies, but also presents new challenges for those who are left behind.

items.summary: A recent webinar, organized by FAO’s Social Protection Team, discusses the importance of gender-sensitive social protection (GSSP) and key dimensions of the GSSP approach, as well as specific lessons learned from FAO’s work in Africa and Latin America.

items.summary: One of a series of interviews with the women scientists aboard the R/V Dr. Fridtjof Nansen, the marine research vessel at the heart of the EAF-Nansen programme.

items.title: Turning the tide: the story of Joyce's fish farm
items.summary: Joyce Makaka owns a fish farm in Kakamega County, in western Kenya. Today, her business is thriving, and employs a team of workers. Yet Joyce remembers when things were not as easy, and she had to struggle to keep her fish farm afloat.

items.summary: In communities throughout Niger, a quiet revolution is underway.

items.summary: She was just 17 when her parents forced her to become a housewife. Her husband already had two wives and children, as well as an extended family of relatives, dependents and apprentices.

items.summary: Cristina Amaral, Deputy Regional Representative for FAO in Europe and Central Asia, discusses the importance of women's rights and gender issues in the context of FAO's work in the region.

items.summary: A simple and relatively inexpensive technology is revolutionizing the way West Africans smoke their fish.

items.title: The female face of street food vending in Ghana

items.title: Snapshot Liberia: “Saving my money for the future.”
items.summary: “I could not write my name. I did not understand how to do my business. I only did the business and was not saving any money.”

items.title: Snapshot Liberia: “I now understand my business...”
items.summary: “As a market woman, I never understood my business. But I now understand my business because I learnt about the importance of saving money.”

items.title: Snapshot Liberia: “I am capable of making an informed decision...”
items.summary: “Before the training, I was unable to manage money. I spent carelessly and did not even recognize that there is a future.”

items.summary: “I am confident that this groundnut cultivation will help educate my children and earn a substantial income for my family” says Nelka Kumari Ariyasena.

items.title: Building leadership: the rural women of FAO-Dimitra
items.summary: Since 2006, Dimitra Clubs have played a crucial role in strengthening rural communities in sub-Saharan Africa, with a special focus on women’s empowerment.

items.title: In Bangladesh: three women, three farmers, three tales of success

items.summary: Research suggests that kitchen gardens can supply up to half of all non-staple food needs, as well as a significant number of vitamins and minerals. This makes them an invaluable tool for food security in vulnerable communities.
